block.p: Lori Michelle Smith, a daughter of Sandy and Dennis Smith of Springfield, N.J., is to be married today to Howard Seth Weiner, a son of Barbara and Harvey Weiner of Wynnewood, Pa. Rabbi Joshua Goldstein is to officiate at the Crystal Plaza, a caterer in Livingston, N.J.

The bride is a speech and language therapist at the St. Francis de Sales School for the Deaf in Brooklyn. Her father is a partner in Clancy, Callahan & Smith, a law firm in Roseland, N.J. Her mother is the Chatham, N.J., public schools' drug and alcohol counselor.

Lori Michelle Smith, a daughter of Sandy and Dennis Smith of Springfield, N.J., is to be married today to Howard Seth Weiner, a son of Barbara and Harvey Weiner of Wynnewood, Pa. Rabbi Joshua Goldstein is to officiate at the Crystal Plaza, a caterer in Livingston, N.J.

The bride is a speech and language therapist at the St. Francis de Sales School for the Deaf in Brooklyn. Her father is a partner in Clancy, Callahan & Smith, a law firm in Roseland, N.J. Her mother is the Chatham, N.J., public schools' drug and alcohol counselor.

The bridegroom is a criminal defense lawyer in Manhattan. His mother is a guidance counselor at the Hillside Elementary School in Berwyn, Pa. His father is the vice president for health affairs at Eagleville Hospital in Eagleville, Pa.

Ms. Smith and Mr. Weiner, both 31, went to George Washington University as undergraduates, but met there only once. She later earned a master's degree in speech and language pathology from Gallaudet University, and he received a degree from Brooklyn Law School.

They did not see each other again until eight years after graduation, on Memorial Day 2000, when Mr. Weiner found himself standing behind Ms. Smith in line at a bakery on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
''I was pretty sure I recognized her,'' he recalled. ''Ordinarily, I'd sit back and say, 'I'll talk to her the next time,' But then I thought: 'What are the chances that I'll see her again?' ''
He asked if she was the same Lori he had met in college. After a few minutes, he grew bolder. ''I grabbed her left hand and said, 'I see there is no ring,' '' he remembered.
Ms. Smith found his approach ''bold, but not macho'' and also ''refreshing.''
Before the end of their brief conversation, he said, ''Maybe we'll go for a drink sometime,'' and he asked for her phone number. ''Turned out she gave me the right one,'' he said.
''I remember thinking when I saw him on Memorial Day that this had happened all on its own -- no setups or blind dates,'' Ms. Smith said. ''After our meeting, I remember skipping home.''
